title: Joaquin Phoenix defends 'Joker' violence: 'It's good that people are having a strong reaction'
text:
Actor Joaquin Phoenix is defending his new Batman movie “Joker” amid criticism that it glorifies violence, saying he felt it necessary in today’s culture to make the audience empathize with the supervillain.

“I didn’t imagine that it would be smooth sailing,” Mr. Phoenix, who plays the Joker in the new movie, told Vanity Fair in an interview published Tuesday. “It’s a difficult film. In some ways, it’s good that people are having a strong reaction to it.”

Critics have accused “Joker” of promoting real-world violence and painting the notorious supervillain as a hero. Earlier this month, families of the victims who were killed during a Batman movie at a theater in Aurora, Colorado, in 2012 wrote a letter to Warner Bros. demanding that the studio donate profits to gun-victim charities.

Warner Bros., as well as the film’s director and executive producer, have all defended the film as necessary in provoking difficult conversations surrounding gun violence and mental health.

“There’s so many different ways of looking at it,” Mr. Phoenix said. “You can either say here’s somebody who, like everybody, needed to be heard and understood and to have a voice. Or you can say this is somebody that disproportionately needs a large quantity of people to be fixated on him. His satisfaction comes as he stands in amongst the madness.

“I was going through [the script] and I realized, I said, ‘Well, why would we make something, like, where you sympathize or empathize with this villain?’ It’s, like, because that’s what we have to do,” he continued. “It’s so easy for us to — we want the simple answers, we want to vilify people. It allows us to feel good if we can identify that as evil. ‘Well, I’m not racist ‘cause I don’t have a Confederate flag or go with this protest.’ It allows us to feel that way, but that’s not healthy because we’re not really examining our inherent racism that most white people have, certainly. Or whatever it may be. Whatever issues you may have. It’s too easy for us and I felt like, yeah, we should explore this villain. This malevolent person.”

In the same interview, “Joker” director Todd Phillips continued his defense of the film, saying people needed to remember that the Joker isn’t a real person.

“We’re making a movie about a fictional character in a fictional world, ultimately, and your hope is that people take it for what it is,” he said. “You can’t blame movies for a world that is so f–ed up that anything can trigger it. That’s kind of what the movie is about. It’s not a call to action. If anything it’s a call to self-reflection to society.”
